As can be seen from Figure 7A, the TRANES showed a prominent maxima at lower delay times (0−2.0 ns) in water.However, at higher delay times, the TRANES undergoes a red shift to ∼540 nm, the region of excimer emission as assigned earlier.Similarly, the TRANES in the solid state undergoes a red shift to ∼500 nm at higher delay times (Figure 7B).The above observations clearly point out the presence of aggregates (at lower delay times) as well as excimer (at higher delay times) in the emission spectrum, which could not be discerned in the steady-state emission spectrum owing to the large difference between the emission lifetime of the aggregate, J or H, with that of excimer.In addition, the clear difference in the TRANES maxima in water and solid state was indicative of the fact that the aggregates formed in water are essentially J-type, whereas those in solid are H-type.The TRANES for the LB films could not be successfully recorded owing to strong scattering from the SA fragments in the films while acquiring the data.At this stage, a thorough discussion was possible to explain the differing emitting species in Py-CHO and their variation upon change in phases (solution in water, solid, and LB films).Discussion on the Differential Nature of Interplay between Aggregates and Excimer.Since the coexistence of aggregate and excimer emission makes the excited-state photophysics of Py-CHO quite complex, a discussion is also presented.The interpretations followed the order THF, water, solid-state, and Py-CHO/SA LB films.In THF, the Py-CHO molecules simply behave as the classic pyrene molecule, with its excited-state photodynamics entirely guided by the monomer ↔ excimer photoequilibrium.The lifetime values of the excimer and monomer were assigned from the TCSPC experiments.In water, the Py-CHO molecules form aggregates (as evidenced from the spectrodynamic experiments) as well as excimers alongside monomers.The nature of aggregates formed was assigned to be J-type, due to their longer emission lifetime compared to the monomers.The reason for preferential stabilization of J aggregates could be twofold: (i) opposing effects of poor stabilization of Py-CHO particles in pure aqueous medium and hydrogen-bonding stabilization of the −CHO group by water molecules and (ii) preferential stabilization of J aggregates owing to dipolar stabilization of the same by the polar water molecules.The assumptions are fortified by the existing experimental and computational reports on preferential stabilization of J aggregates in pyrene, perylene, and porphyrin derivatives.57−60 In the solid state, the excited-state photophysics is dominated by monomers, excimers, and H aggregates, as observed from the excited-state lifetime measurements.The reason for this assignment was based on the assumption of parallel stacking of the Py-CHO molecules, facilitating extended nonclassical CH···π interactions in the solid state.Such an arrangement could be preferred over the J-type arrangement due to lack of external dipolar stabilization of the −CHO group as in the case of water.Such stabilization has been observed previously for conjugated pyrene derivatives in the solid state.9,61,62 In the Py-CHO/SA LB films, the situation is more interesting owing to the presence of SA molecules.Since SA- based LB films are typically composed of a reticular framework, the Py-CHO molecules are “trapped” in the matrix in various The excitation source and delay time are mentioned in the inset.Langmuir

Compressibility coefficient CS−1 [mN/m] values of the tested systems: PI (−), PI+AA (−), PI+EAA (−), PI+P2 (−), PI+P2+AA (−), PI+P2+EAA (−), PI+P4 (−), PI+P4+AA (−), and PI+P4+EAA (−) at temperatures of 20 ◦C, 25 ◦C, 30 ◦C, and 35 ◦C.The purple line indicates the boundary between the expanded liquid phase and the condensed liquid phase.2.3.Compression and Expansion of the Monolayer Formed from PI with Peptides, AA, and EAA in the Aqueous Subphase The compression and decompression isotherms for the PI monolayer in the water subphase with AA and EAA at temperatures of 20◦C, 25 ◦C, 30 ◦C, and 35 ◦C are presented as three hysteresis loops, as shown in Figures S9–S12.At temperatures of 20 ◦C, 25 ◦C, and 30 ◦C, the hysteresis of the PI monolayer in the water subphase with AA and EAA exhibited a similar shape, and the width of each successive loop decreased to a small extent.The situation was similar at 35 ◦C, with the hysteresis of the PI monolayer with AA clearly shifting towards smaller surfaces.At all temperatures, decompression did not follow the compression path and the range in which the hysteresis occurred was within the surface pressure range from about 0 to 33.4 mN/m.The course of the hysteresis of the monolayer formed from PI with peptides, AA, and EAA in the aqueous subphase is shown in Figures S13–S16.In the course of the hysteresis at 30 ◦C and 35 ◦C, the decompression did not follow the compression.At both temperatures, a similar loop shape could be observed, which was characterized by an emerging flattening on the compression line.The hysteresis of the PI monolayer over P2 and EAA at 30 ◦C occurred in a larger range of surface pressure compared to the hysteresis of the PI monolayer over P2 and AA.The hysteresis of the PI monolayer in the PI+P4, PI+P4+AA, and PI+P4+EAA systems is shown in Figures S17–S20.At the first three temperatures, the hysteresis of the PI monolayer over P4 shifted toward smaller areas compared to the hysteresis for the PI+P4+AA and PI+P4+EAA systems.At 35 ◦C, the compression and decompression for the three hysteresis loops were close to each other for the PI+P4 system.The successive hysteresis loops of the PI+P4+EAA system ran close to each other at all temperatures.

and PI+P4+EAA (— ).3.Discussion Due to the increasing resistance of bacteria, including C.acnes, to the antibiotics used so far, new methods for treating bacterial infections are being sought [15].As the newly synthesized peptides (WKWK)2-KWKWK-NH2 and (C12)2-KKKK-NH2 are known to have many physicochemical properties that can potentially be used to create prospective drugs, their eﬀect on a monolayer composed of a component of Cutibacterium membranes, i.e., phosphatidylinositol, was investigated.By analyzing the course of the surface pressure dependence on the surface area per molecule in the form of π-A isotherms, it was possible to determine the interactions between the phosphatidylinositol molecules in the monolayer and the components of the aqueous subphase.Initially, compression isotherms were measured for the phosphatidylinositol monolayer, which served as a reference for the remaining monolayers with the addition of AA and EAA and antimicrobial peptides.The addition of only the P2 and P4 peptides to the subphase shifted the compression isotherm toward smaller surfaces, which may be the result of interactions with the groups of the monolayer that favor higher organization (Figure 3) [16].The lack of a decrease in the surface pressure at which the plateau be gins, observed in the PI–P4 system, may be explained by the fact that P4 has the most  lipophilic character compared to the other peptides.This high lipophilicity is determined by two hydrophobic chains in its structure, which, in the case of a highly ﬂuidiﬁed monolayer, may penetrate between the phospholipid molecules in an a ttempt to “get out” to the water surface [17].In the expanded liquid phase, the PI monolayer provides enough space so that P4s hydrophobic interactions with the monolayer can occur more easily.Consequently, in the case of the condensed liquid phase, the main e ﬀect is peptide binding and the subsequent condensation of the monolayer [18].The interactions between the peptide and phospholipid molecules lead to the signiﬁcant reorientation or even disintegration of the ordered structure of the peptide and play a condensing role, leading to increased ordering of the alkyl chain in the phospholipid monolayer [19].systems: PI (—), PI+AA (—), PI+EAA (—), PI+P2 (—), PI+P2+AA (—), PI+P2+EAA (—), PI+P4 (—), PI+P4+AA (—), and PI+P4+EAA (—).3.Discussion =4 are attributed to the decrease in NInt of the [TFSA] − anion as the alkyl chain length increases at the CCl4 interface.V.DISCUSSION We briefly review the structural information of the CCl4/[Cnmim][TFSA] and air/[C nmim][TFSA] interfaces.The terminal CH3 group of the alkyl chain of the [Cnmim]+ cation faces toward the CCl4 phase.This is indicated by the peak positions of the r+ and r− modes of the terminal CH 3 group at the CCl 4 interface, which are red-shifted from those at the air interface, as well as the peak broadening of the r + and r − modes at the CCl 4 interface.The SF signal amplitude of the r + mode is almost independent of the alkyl chain length at the CCl 4 interfaces, similar to the case of the air interface, indicating that NInt and f(Ω) of the [C nmim]+ cation do not change much between n = 4 and 8.The lower χ values of the r + mode at the CCl 4 interface than those at the air interface are attributed to the lower NInt and broader f(Ω) of the [Cnmim]+ cation at the CCl 4 interface.In addition, χ(d+)/χ(r+) of the [C8mim]+ cation is lower at the CCl 4 interface than that at the air interface, which reflects the fewer gauche defects in the octyl chain of the [C8mim]+ cation at the CCl4 interface.The red-shifted d+ and r+ mode peaks of the [C8mim]+ cation at the CCl4 interface vs the air interface allow us to conclude that the octyl chain of the [C8mim]+ cation is well solvated by the CCl 4 molecules, reducing the number of gauche defects.At the CCl4 interface, the SO2 and CF3 groups of the [TFSA]− anion face toward the RTIL and CCl 4 phases, respectively, as indi- cated by the similar peak positions of the SO 2-ss and CF3-ss modes in the SFG spectra of the air and CCl 4 interfaces and in the IR spectra of the bulk RTIL.The orientational analysis using the calculated nonlinear susceptibility components indicates that the [TFSA]− anion orientation does not change much between n = 4 and 8, but differs at the CCl 4 and air interfaces as follows: the S–S vector is nearly parallel to the CCl4 interface but is tilted away from the air interface.The SF signal amplitude derived from the [TFSA]− anion is lower forn =8 than for n =4 at the CCl4 interface, similar to that at the air interface, which corresponds to the lower NInt of the [TFSA]− anion when n =8.Figures 8(c) and 8(d) schematically illustrate the structures of the CCl4/[Cnmim][TFSA] interface, which are based on that of the air/[Cnmim][TFSA] interface shown in Figs.8(a) and 8(b).36 Here, as we reported for the air interface, 36 we can safely assume that the CCl4 interface has a bi-layering structure; the first layer [pale blue region in Figs.8(b) and 8(d)] and the second layer [pale red region in Figs.8(b) and 8(d)] arrange themselves with “head-to-head” ion orientation at their shared boundary, because the effective number density of the anion decreases from n =4 to 8.Both the [C nmim]+ cation and [TFSA] − anion in the first layer are polar oriented such that the nonpolar groups (the alkyl chain and CF 3 group) point toward the CCl4 phase, while the polar groups (the imidazolium ring and SO2 group) face the RTIL phase.This orientation enables the CCl4 molecules to solvate the alkyl chains of the [C nmim]+ cations and the CF3 groups of the [TFSA]− anions.A.Solvation effect on the [Cn mim]+ cation at the CCl4/RTIL interface The number of gauche defects in the octyl chain of the [C8mim]+ cation is lower at the CCl4 interface than at the air inter- face [Figs.8(b) and 8(d)].This is in contrast with the case of the Langmuir film on the water surface, which has more gauche defects at the CCl4 interface than at the air interface,30–33 indicating that the solvation effect of CCl4 on the RTIL surface differs from that on the Langmuir film.The alkyl chain conformation at the interface can be simply discussed in terms of the free energy:F =U −TS.61 The pres- ence of gauche defects in the alkyl chain increases the entropy, S, of the alkyl chain, which results in a decrease in the free energy, F.61 At the liquid/liquid interface, solvation (mixing) by the contacting liquid molecules increases the entropy term of mixing, Smix.The higher number of gauche defects in the Langmuir film at the CCl 4 interface than at the air interface 30–33 indicates that the J.Chem.Phys.162, 014705 (2025); doi: FIG.8 Schematic structural models of the (a) air/[C 4mim][TFSA], (b) air/[C8mim][TFSA], (c) CCl 4/[C4mim] [TFSA], and (d) CCl 4/[C8mim][TFSA] interfaces.The pale blue and red regions in (b) and (d) represent the first and second layers, respectively.These layers are arranged in a “head-to-head” ion orientation at their shared bound- ary, which constitutes the bi-layering structure.alkyl chains are less solvated by CCl 4, lowering Smix, which reflects the solvophobic effect.31 By contrast, the lower number of gauche defects in the alkyl chains of the cations at the CCl4/[C8mim][TFSA] interface than at the air/[C8mim][TFSA] interface indicates that the alkyl chains are well solvated by CCl4, increasing Smix, which reflects the solvophilic effect.The surface number density of the alkyl chain at the [C 8mim][TFSA] surface (1.53 ×1014 cm−2)36 is much lower than that of the Langmuir film on water (3.6 × 1014 cm−2).30,31 Therefore, the loosely packed octyl chains at the [C 8mim][TFSA] surface reduce the number of gauche defects in their conformation at the CCl4 interface, being well solvated by CCl4 and yielding a high Smix value.This scenario is in contrast with that of the dense alkyl chains of the Langmuir film.The term of internal energyU, which is dominated by the interaction between the ions and CCl 4, including the Madelung energy as a long-range electrostatic interaction, also contributes to the structural formation at the RTIL/CCl 4 interface.The theoretical treatment of the internal energy U at the interface is under consideration and will be presented in the near future.B.Solvation effect on the [TFSA]− anion at the CCl4/RTIL interface The orientation of the [TFSA]− anion at the CCl4 interface dif- fers from that at the air interface, as shown in Fig.8.The SO2 groups of the [TFSA]− anion face toward the RTIL phase at the CCl4 and air interfaces, but the S–S vector is nearly parallel to the CCl 4 interface and is tilted away from the air interface.This indicates that the area occupied by the [TFSA] − anion is larger at the CCl 4 interface than that at the air interface, which is in good agreement with the smaller interface number density of the cation at the CCl 4 interface than at the air interface.Such an orientational change of the [TFSA]− anion at the CCl4 interface may be due to the solvation effect of CCl4 on the [TFSA]− anion and/or on the alkyl chains of the [Cnmim]+ cation.The area occupied by CCl 4 is estimated to be 32 Å 2 based on the van der Waals volume and is smaller than that of the [TFSA] − anion (39 Å2) at the CCl4 interface, as shown in Figs.7(a) and 7(b).This indicates that the alkyl chains of the cations are well solvated by CCl4 as compared to those at the air interface, where the occupation area of the [TFSA]−anion is 26 Å2, as shown in Fig.7(c).In addition, the nearly identical peak positions of the CF 3-ss and SO2-ss modes of the [TFSA]− anion at the CCl4 and air interfaces indicate that the interaction of the [TFSA]− anion with CCl4 is negligible.Hence, the orientational change of the [TFSA]− anion to increase its area at the CCl4 interface is accompanied by the solvophilic effect of CCl 4 on the alkyl chains of the [C nmim]+ cation, which expands the space among the [Cnmim]+ cations.The MD simulation study on the spatial distribution of the anion around the cation in the bulk RTIL reveals the diffuse sol- vation shell of the [TFSA] − anion around the imidazolium ring of the [C 4mim]+ cation.62,63 This is caused by the weak basicity and acidity of the anion and cation, respectively, allowing for a flexible anion–cation arrangement.62,63 The flexibility enables the orienta- tional change of the [TFSA]− anion accompanied by the solvophilic effect of CCl 4 on the alkyl chains of the [C nmim]+ cations.Con- sequently, the solvophilic effect of CCl 4 at the CCl 4/RTIL interface originates from the loosely packed alkyl chains of the cation at the RTIL surface, along with the flexible anion–cation arrangement with the weak basicity and acidity of the ions of the RTILs.This differs from the solvophobic effect 31 of CCl4 on the dense alkyl chains of the Langmuir film with a rather rigid molecular arrangement owing to the strong basicity and acidity of the headgroup and counter ion of the ionic surfactant.30–33 VI.CONCLUSION We conducted an IV-SFG vibrational spectroscopic analysis to determine the microscopic structure at the CCl 4/[Cnmim][TFSA] (n = 4 and 8) interface and compared it with the structure at the air/[Cnmim][TFSA] interface.A quantitative analysis of the SFG spectra in the C–H stretch region revealed the [C nmim]+ cation conformation/orientation at the CCl 4 interfaces as follows.(i) The terminal CH3 group of the alkyl chain of the [Cnmim]+ cation inter- acts with the CCl 4 phase.(ii) The interface number densities of the [C nmim]+ cation at the CCl 4 interface for alkyl chain lengths n = 4 and 8 are similar but assemble supported lipid bilayers (SLB) as an alternative to direct deposition of liposomes onto solid supports; these bilayers are used as archetypes for cell membranes.148−150 4.LANGMUIR MONOLAYERS IN MIMICKING CELL MEMBRANES An uprise in the interest in Langmuir monolayers occurred with their use as models for cell membranes.Understanding the structure and physicochemical properties of biomembranes is not straightforward, and much of the knowledge we have today has been achieved with the continuous development of model systems that mimic cell membranes.These membranes are highly complex, not only in terms of composition but also because of interweaved ordered or disordered structures.They are supramolecular assemblies whose molecular entities determine the organization at both macro- and molecular scales.The pioneering work by Singer and Nicolson151 described a cell membrane as a“mosaic ﬂuid”, i.e., two lipid bilayers interconnected by interactions between their lipid alkyl chains, permitting their polar heads to be exposed to the external and internal side of the cell.Theﬂuidity mentioned suggests that the lipids can move laterally inside their monolayer sheath, and some lipids can slowly migrate between the two bilayer sheaths in the so-called“ﬂip-ﬂop” movement.The mosaic ﬂuid model was updated a few years ago.152 Cell membranes contain lipids, proteins, and sugars to maintain the dynamic equilibrium and allow for diﬀerent cell functions, such as the permeation of components into or out of the cell and molecular recognition processes.Because Langmuir mono- layers can mimic only half a membrane, they are not suitable to investigate transport across the membrane.Hence, other models can be used as complementary, including liposomes, micelles, ﬂat bilayers, and black lipid membranes.These artiﬁcially built models vary in the ability to control molecular composition, organization, curvature, and electrochemical gradient.Langmuir monolayers, in particular, are advantageous to control composition and surface packing.Whether these monolayers can mimic the membranes, which are at least bilayers, has been debated for many years regarding the relationship between monolayers and bilayers.153−160 Although bilayers cannot exert surface pressure because they are closed systems, we can describe an internal lateral pressure based on the intermolecular forces between the lipid constituents, estimating a monolayer−bilayer equivalence pressure of 30− 35 mN/m.153,160 Langmuir monolayers can mimic various types of biological surfaces, including the cytoplasmatic membrane, the mitochon- drial membrane, the vesicular matrix, and virus envelopes.An interesting case is related to pulmonary alveolar membranes since a pulmonary surfactant forms a monolayer that reduces surface tension during breathing.161,162 The lung surfactant composition comprises 40% DPPC,∼40% other phospholipids (PG, other PC),∼10% surfactant proteins (SP-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D), and ∼10% neutral lipids (cholesterol).163 DPPC can reduce surface tension to values close to zero, which can be understood by analyzing its surface pressure−area isotherms: as a saturated lipid, it reaches the collapse at surface pressures close to 70 mN/m.This fact is important because the alveolar membrane must compress and expand rapidly during exhalation and inhalation, which occurs due to the membrane’s interface onto solid supports (substrates).Chemical Reviews

Liquid–liquid interfacial assembled 2D protein monolayer nanosheet based culture system for hMSC fate controlling.(A) A photograph and illustrations present the formation of a protein monolayer at the liquid–liquid interface, resulting from the denaturation and self-assembly of serum proteins.The response of hMSCs to the stiﬀness of the protein monolayer is clariﬁed through the actin–integrin–ﬁbronectin (FN) clutch mechanism.(B) Lysozyme monolayers, self-assembled at the liquid interface, are shown to maintain the self-renewal and multipotency of hMSCs.The lysozyme forms a close-packed monolayer through hydrophobic interactions amongb-sheet-rich oligomers.Enhancing the retention of multipotency by reducing cytoskeletal tension and glycolysis activity was veriﬁed.Theﬁgure also labels key glycolytic intermediates: fructose 6-phosphate (F6P) and fructose 1,6-bisphosphate (F1,6BP).(C) The adaptive self-assembled protein monolayer is responsive to the traction forces produced by cells, which in turn guides the diﬀerentiation of hMSCs.(D) Theﬁgure illustrates the neuronal diﬀerentiation of hMSCs at the interface, where a 2D network of protein nanoﬁbrils is assembled.This diﬀerentiation process is related to lipid raft assembly and the phosphorylation of focal adhesion kinase (FAK).Reprinted with permission from ref.123 Copyright 2019 Wiley-VCH, ref.124 Copyright 2023 Wiley-VCH, and ref.125 Copyright 2019 Wiley-VCH.Reproduced under terms of the CC-BY license from ref.126, 2022 Springer-Nature.18742 | Chem.Sci.,2 0 2 4 ,15,1 8 7 1 5–18750 © 2024 The Author(s).Published by the Royal Society of Chemistry Chemical Science Review Open Access Article.Published on 28 October 2024.Downloaded on 12/1/2024 12:51:41 PM.This article is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported Licence.View Article Online
